qas.question: Through Molecular studies, what was used to suggest new relationships among mammal families?
During these Molecular studies, which three major groups of mammals shared a common ancestors from the Cretaceous period?
Afrotheria,Xenartha, and Boreoeutheria deprives from which two lineages?
What have studies based on Boreoeutheria suggested?
What have findings based on common ancestors in the Cretaceous been validated by?
What are three major groups of Laurasiatheria?

plausible_answers.text: early common ancestors in the Cretaceous

qas.question: Where did Euarchontoglires and Laurasiatheria come from?
What two major common ancestors does Alantogenata contain?

context: Molecular studies based on <a0_0>DNA analysis<a0_0/> have suggested <b3_0>new relationships among mammal families<b3_0/> over the last few years. Most of these findings have been independently validated by <b4_0>retrotransposon presence/absence data<b4_0/>. Classification systems based on molecular studies reveal three major groups or lineages of placental mammals- <a1_0><b5_0>Afrotheria, Xenarthra, and Boreoeutheria<b5_0/><a1_0/>- which diverged from <b6_0>early common ancestors in the Cretaceous<b6_0/>. The relationships between these three lineages is contentious, and all three possible different hypotheses have been proposed with respect to which group is basal with respect to other placentals. These hypotheses are Atlantogenata (basal Boreoeutheria), Epitheria (basal Xenarthra), and Exafroplacentalia (basal Afrotheria). Boreoeutheria in turn contains two major lineages- <a2_0><b7_0>Euarchontoglires and Laurasiatheria<b7_0/><a2_0/>.
